image.altText: Photo from behind of two women holding hands at a commission of inquiry.

image.altText: The hand of a man in a suit checking the ASX website on his phone at the ASX.

props.synopsis: The Australian share market has fallen to its lowest level since July 10, while the US dollar rises to a 10-month high on bets interest rates may stay higher for longer than investors had expected. Follow the latest updates in our live blog.

title.children: ASX slips to 11-week low, Wall Street snaps four-day losing streak

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Australian share market has slipped in morning trade, with ASX 200 down 0.5% to 7,039 points. This takes the local bourse down to its lowest level since July 10 (considering the ASX dropped 2.9% last week, and has lost 3.5% since the beginning of September ). Most sectors are in the red, with real estate (-1.6%), materials (-0.8%) and technology (-0.6%) suffering the biggest losses. The worst-performing stocks include Megaport (-5.3%), Chalice Mining (-3.7%) and Charter Hall Social Infrastructure REIT (-3.5%). Healthcare is the only sector trading higher, led by gains in the share price of Pro Medicus (+9.4%) and Telix Pharmaceuticals (+1.2%).
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX slips to 10-week low, dragged lower by mining and property stocks

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Australia's richest person Gina Rinehart has spent another $132 million to up her strategic stake in lithium explorer (and takeover target) Liontown Resources. Liontown is currently the subject of a $6.6 billion takeover bid by US chemicals giant Albemarle. It's possible that Ms Rinehart's intervention could force Albermarle to amend its bid for the Western Australia lithium explorer. How much does Rinehart own? Ms Rinehart's Hancock Prospecting group now controls 235.5 million shares in Liontown (or 10.69% of the company). That's a significant increase from a fortnight ago – when Liontown revealed that Ms Rinehart controlled almost 170 million shares (or 7.7% of the company). Over the past two weeks, Ms Rinehart's company has been buying Liontown shares (at $3 per share). Albemarle is about halfway through its one-month period of exclusive due diligence — scrutinising the progress at Liontown's facility at Kathleen Valley (which is still under construction). Liontown said it would start producing lithium in around nine months.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Gina Rinehart increases stake in lithium company Liontown Resources

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: It seems Qantas just can't catch a break. The latest in this slow-motion train wreck is that pilots are calling for Qantas chairman Richard Goyder to step down. This is the first time such a call has been made by the Australian and International Pilots Association (AIPA). In a statement, the association said it had written to Qantas chief executive Vanessa Hudson to inform her of the pilots' position. "Richard Goyder has overseen one of the most damaging periods in Qantas history which has included the illegal sacking of 1,700 workers, allegations of illegally marketing cancelled flights, and a terribly managed return to operations after Covid-19," AIPA president Tony Lucas said. "The morale of Qantas pilots has never been lower. We have totally lost confidence in Goyder and his Board. "Qantas desperately needs a culture reset but how can this happen with Richard Goyder as chairman? "Despite overseeing the destruction of the Qantas brand, Goyder last week accepted a near $100,000 pay rise — taking his pay to $750,000 — while staff are expected to accept a two-year wage freeze. This is a galling and tone-deaf decision." Here's the latest report from our senior business correspondent Peter Ryan :
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Pilots call for Qantas chairman Richard Goyder to step down

props.synopsis: This morning's news, as it happens.

title.children: 'I don't know what makes a chair resign': Shorten weighs in on Qantas. The latest news with The Loop

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The federal government says coins featuring King Charles III will be released before the end of this year. The Royal Mint produced six effigies of Queen Elizabeth II on Australian currency during her 70-year reign. Assistant Treasury Minister Andrew Leigh says developing a new coin is a long process. "There's a range of things we need to get right, the mint's dies need to be appropriately tested, each of the dies need to sustain some 200-to-300,00 coin printings, so all of that testing process is in place," he said. "I'm keen to make sure we get a lot of those new coins out. I know for the vast majority of Australians this will be the first time they hold a coin that has a King and not a Queen on it, so it's a big moment."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Expect to see King Charles on your coins before the year ends

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Actor David McCallum, who became a teen heart-throb in the hit series The Man From U.N.C.L.E. in the 1960s and was the eccentric medical examiner in the popular NCIS 40 years later, has died. He was 90. McCallum died on Monday of natural causes surrounded by family at New York Presbyterian Hospital, TV network CBS said in a statement. "David was a gifted actor and author, and beloved by many around the world. He led an incredible life, and his legacy will forever live on through his family and the countless hours on film and television that will never go away," the network said.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: David McCallum, star of NCIS, dies at 90

featuredLink.title: David McCallum, star of hit TV series The Man From U.N.C.L.E. and NCIS, dies at 90

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: A Senate inquiry into the decision to block more Qatar Airways flights into Australia reconvenes today in Brisbane. Bridget McKenzie, the Shadow Minister for Transport, spoke to News Breakfast a little earlier and says the "end result" for Qantas chairman Richard Goyder will be "a matter for shareholders." "But I think to the pilots' points, Qantas as a corporate citizen has not covered itself in glory in recent past," she said. "We have seen their former CEO set up a scheme for a very, very cosy retirement. "We have seen Qantas, and the Qantas group more broadly including Jetstar, trying to keep over $500 million of their own customers' money through those COVID flight credits. "We have seen the High Court deem that they illegally sacked 1,700 workers and the ACCC is taking them to court over ghost flights. "So on any marker, they are not behaving as we'd expect a corporate citizen to in this country and that's something for shoulders to deal with."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Bridget McKenzie says Qantas chairman's 'end result' up to shareholders

children.content: A Senate inquiry into the decision to block more Qatar Airways flights into Australia reconvenes today in Brisbane.
